description:
@ Kiwi PyCon 2013 - Saturday, 07 Sep 2013 - Track 1

**Audience level**

Novice

**Abstract**

This talk will cover:

 * What autopilot is, how it's made, and how it works.
 * How we use it at Canonical, and what benefits we've seen from using it.
 * How you can use it to test your own applications.

**Slides**

https://speakerdeck.com/nzpug/thomi-richards-using-autopilot-for-functional-ui-testing
embed: <object width="640" height="390"><param name="movie" value="http://youtube.com/v/1NrykxuCcM0?version=3&hl=en_US"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://youtube.com/v/1NrykxuCcM0?version=3&hl=en_US" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="390" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object>
summary: Autopilot is a tool designed for writing high-level functional tests for GUI applications. It is written by a team of engineers at Canonical, and is being used to test everything from the Unity desktop shell to desktop applications, to core phone applications for the Ubuntu Touch project.
title: Using Autopilot for Functional UI Testing
